content.content: Has anyone been impacted recently by supply chain issues? Any idea on why that’s the case? Globalization is great, until it wasn’t. It’s actually a pretty simple problem to identify, blockages. For example, automobiles require semiconductors. When chips to build cars aren’t available, production lines slow or stop. Let’s say we get some chips and start production again but then we have a shortage in one of the raw materials to build tires. Cars can’t roll off of the assembly line. What just happened? We’ve simply shifted the issue from chips to tires. The net result was the same, we didn’t ship as many cars as we would have liked. Or maybe none at all. This concept of shifting the issue is directly applicable to what I see happening in the DAO today. When there is a blockage, enterprising people try to find ways around it. Many times, this indicates issues with a lack of direction. Personally, I’m intrigued when I see these actions since it means people are paying attention. Engagement is a key quality for anything to be successful. What is important to understand is that shifting an issue isn’t the same as solving the issue. I can be a shifter all day long…I just make it someone else’s problem.  It’s About What I am asking is for the community to help us solve some really important issues. MakerDAO is a community driven project and it’s not only critical but imperative for us to work together. Everyone, it’s about Prioritization AND Transparency! I’ll share with you that this isn’t about collateral. It’s just that the first clear manifestation of this IS about collateral. As one example, the shift from chips to tires with MakerDAO collateral is about moving collateral Prioritization and Assessments deeper into the process.  COB Process Flow-lines1393×717 80.6 KB  Moving collateral Prioritization and Assessments into the Implementation phase changes very little. We still have to prioritize the work keeping in mind there are also competing priorities within and between Core Units and collateral types (on/off chain). In addition, this shifting has the potential to skip an important phase where the community holds an onchain vote based upon detailed Assessments from the Domain Teams. Things like this come up to help us understand the risk we are voting on:   We don’t believe there is a rock solid legal agreement to ensure the DAO will be repaid   On Emergency Shutdown, vault holders own a fraction of something that doesn’t exist   If we had a significant liquidation event, we could take a 50% haircut on this token   We will always have an over abundance of work and limited resources. This is a constant in all organizations. What’s the solution? With a clear vision and stated objectives, it’s about focus and only doing the most important work. Decentralization doesn’t make this issue go away…it only makes it more challenging. By its nature, prioritization is a flawed process. It’s about alignment, not agreement. It always has an element of subjectivity. It requires us to check out egos and biases at the door and come into the room with the common goal of doing what is best for the Maker protocol based upon higher level objectives. We also have to find alignment in the context of a profit motive (including the DAO) and building with the protocol.  My Ask I am asking the community to help us fix the prioritization issue. Today, we have a collateral process that includes a Prioritization phase and it’s broken. Trying to ignore this and onboard collateral by brute force will not change that problem. During the next round of MIPs (May cycle), the community will see an expansion of this approach which will not only create more ambiguity but CUs spending hours of non-productive work in the forums and increased bottlenecks with implementation. If there was a simple solution, we would have done it already. I can talk for an hour on why Prioritization is broken. It doesn’t matter unless we fix it. Help me do this by voting NO on any MIPs that include prioritization and/or blocking language. The reason I ask for this is so we can place all of our energies on fixing the issues and not moving the problem around. There is A LOT of progress being made right now and more coming to help clarify, educate, prioritize, assess, and share the progress of collateral being onboarded into the protocol. Given our current process, all indications show me that the future will be a collaborative process in which the community plays a much greater role than today. Please attend the CES CU Quarterly Update meeting where the CES team will share with you our progress in Q1, plans for Q2, and a bit more detail on the above. All ideas on how to solve these issues is encouraged and welcomed. Thanks!

Good overview of the problem you are giving. It seems to me that this is not just your problem. The novel structure of the DAO means that everyone is looking for efficient ways of working. And not only here.  People are always looking for faster ways to get ahead by using shortcuts and loopholes. Fortunately for us, if we can identify the flaws, at this stage the system can be easily shaped to work more efficiently. This is an advantage over traditional, rigid systems that is key to our survival. We could decide to leave the “roads in the DAO” unpaved for a good while yet, let people develop the paths needed for the DAO to work effectively, and then pave them later.     monkey.irish:  Has anyone been impacted recently by supply chain issues?   Is there anyone here who is not somehow affected by this?

monkey.irish:   We don’t believe there is a rock solid legal agreement to ensure the DAO will be repaid On Emergency Shutdown, vault holders own a fraction of something that doesn’t exist If we had a significant liquidation event, we could take a 50% haircut on this token    I don’t think it’s fair to say that these problems exist for MIP65. It’s very clear that an onboarding can only occur if there are public verifications of the actual, de facto, implemented structures and agreements. Regarding general legal structure, and emergency shutdown (and other edge cases) these conditions must be verified:  No ability by third parties or Monetalis to access the funds or change the terms of the legal structure Maker Governance has complete ability to trigger a liquidation with a successful executive vote encoding an instruction to the trustee of the structure. It should not be possible for a single third party to block the ability of Maker Governance to make decisions or modify the structure. There must be no apparent weak links or edge cases that allow funds to get misappropriated or stuck.  If these things cannot be verified to be true by RWF (which would in practice be done by Christian), the onboarding doesn’t occur. The verification isn’t of a plan or hypothetical scenario, it’s a verification of the actual, implemented, executed, de facto structures and agreements once they are fully set up and ready to receive the Dai. Similar verification is required by Strategic Finance to ensure the liquidity of the assets. Again, if the assets aren’t verified to be appropriate for providing large scale liquidity, the onboarding doesn’t occur. And again, this is a verification of the actual, de facto, fully implemented and executed agreements and structures once they are a 100% complete stage and ready to receive Dai. It is only in that absolute and fully completed stage that it is ever even possible to make any kind of verification of the security and risk of an RWA structure. But the reality is that almost nobody would ever front hundreds of thousands of dollars to fully implement and execute a legal structure before they have any idea if it will be approved or not. A greenlight or some other non-MIP vote or process isn’t enough, if it doesn’t control prioritization and doesn’t guarantee onboarding at set risk parameters. The onboarding could always be delayed indefinitely, or even it it got prioritized there could be additional votes or decisions by core units that might change risk parameters or cancel it etc. Only a MIP has the necessary force to provide the guarantees that such things won’t happen - the only risk after MIP approval, is a cancel vote that must be actively triggered as signal request, which is a risk that is much more realistic to expect legitimate collateral providers to swallow and give them the confidence to pay the huge expenses to get a large scale RWA legal structure executed. And in general I really don’t see the problem with using a new approach, if the new approach works. The whole point is that for very large and valuable deals, the current process doesn’t really work, and has gotten jammed. So the most important reaction to that should be to start building momentum by doing something that works, and start getting things done. We shouldn’t fall into the trap of moving from being stuck in the process itself, to then being stuck trying to come up with some kind of new process that will solve the problem. In the very short term, we should just focus on doing things and that’s what stand alone MIPs are perfect for. Then once we have started to actually doing things, then we can look at the patterns and experiences of what we’ve achieved, and try to use that to create a future proofed process. But as long as we are still creating the process, and as long as it still isn’t done and ready to take over and be fully able to do the things we want to do, we should not hold back from making sure that our top priority is to actually keep doing things. One last important piece of context for this post is that I’m only talking about large scale deals here, 100 million+ debt ceiling. We have so many billions of USDC sitting around that must be activated that IMO it only makes sense to look at possibilities that are actually scalable. And so a final but really important point to make is that MIP65 does not block or reprioritize large scale deals, since it has an exception for onboardings of assets with a debt ceiling of more than 100 million. So the worst case scenario is that it blocks or interferes with a small collateral onboarding. Waiting on small deals in order to enable large deals to go through is the essence of proper prioritization IMO.
